moves.1. e4 c6: The Caro-Kann, a relatively new defense at the time.
moves.2. Nc3: Instead of setting up an ideal center with P-Q4, Lasker first develops a Knight.
moves.2... d5: Without Lasker's QP in the center, this move threatens to seize it for Black.
moves.3. Nf3: Lasker keeps developing. Now if Black exchanges Pawns...
moves.4... Bf5: Black attempts to drive Lasker's Knight from is central post.
moves.5. Ng3: Instead of moving back to QB3, Lasker counterattacks Black's Bishop.
moves.5... Bg6: The other choice, keeping the B on its original diagonal, was 5... B-Q2.
moves.6... h6: Black creates a retreat for the B and guards against 7 N-N5.
moves.7. Ne5: With N-N5 impossible, Lasker chooses this square instead.
moves.7... Bh7: The B retreats into the hidey-hole.
moves.8. Qh5: Lasker focuses attention on the natural weakness at KB7.
moves.9. Bc4: Pressuring KB7 again. Now 9... PxQ??? 10 BxP mate!
moves.9... e6: Cutting off another diagonal and creating a flight square at K2.
moves.10. Qe2: With the Queen out of danger, Lasker now threatens down the K file.
moves.10... Bg7: Trying to chase the Knight. But...
moves.11. Nxf7: Forking Q and R. If 11... KxN, 12 QxP ch K-B1 13 Q-B7 mate. So Black resigns.
